http://ask.fm/Sylvetican 

> [[ BROKEN SKY ONLINE ]]

> [[ Conflict resolution is decided by the highest of three 1d100 rolls. ]]
> [[ Rolls of 1-3 or 98-100 will yield “enhanced effect”, an especially poor or especially good outcome. ]]
> [[ These two outcomes offset each other when occuring simultaneously, yielding a normal outcome. ]]
> [[ A true critical failure occurs when a 1-3 is rolled, and all rolls are below the target number before modifiers. ]]
> [[ A true critical success occurs when a 98-100 is rolled, and all rolls are above the target number after modifiers. ]]
> [[ Critical successes will also occur if two rolls are within the critical success threshold, unless the third roll is within the critical failure threshold. ]]
> [[ However, the same will apply to critical failures.]]

> [[ Ascheritte's skills and passive abilities provide bonuses and modifiers to rolls. ]] 
> [[ Modifiers and target numbers remain hidden currently, but a skill's degree of effect should be evident through its description. ]]
> [[ Active abilities can be used freely, but some are reactionary, and will be prompted during combat. ]]

44267459.name: Sylvetica
44267459.comment:
>>44267443

Screams reverberate throughout the halls of the Upper Sanctum as you, Aelriss, and Nel sprint back through the winding passages, passing myriad doors—all alike—before the landing comes into view, a stiffly-neat and stocked study, with library shelves lined up on either side of the path leading back to the spiral staircase. Someone or something isn’t happy with you—at least, at possible worst; at possible best, you’ve simply startled a group of tenants who don’t get too many visitors. Ahead, the rest of the party is primed and ready; Kainzo is at the head of the group, which stands in a haphazard formation, each member visibly prepared to fight, though unsure of which direction foes could approach from.

“Nel!” Ayla says.

“You made it back in one piece, kid.” Donnel adds.

The screaming sounds are distant and echoic enough that the conversation can be heard over them without necessitating a raise in volume—but it’s an eerie backdrop, and one that isn’t particularly pleasing to the ear anyway. You feel uneasy.

“Barely.” Nel breathes a sigh of relief. “Would have been done for were it not for Ashe.”

“Ascheritte. Report?” Kainzo asks.

“An entire room of those homunculi—dolls made in the image of Kjorikos’s dead lover.” Aelriss says, before you can come through with a response of your own. “It’s worse than we thought. He didn’t just try one or two more times after the first one didn’t come through…”

To the right, a bookshelf suddenly collapses, liberating a thick cloud of dust that produces another pair of the marbleized humanoids—varying in height, with cracked, cream-colored skin, eyes and mouths closed and perfectly still. Then, a pair of the translucent Sanctum windows fall forward, shattering on the ground and revealing themselves not as portals to the outside, but as gateways to small compartments that contain more of the ghastly things.

> [[ Continued ]]

44267493.name: Sylvetica
44267493.comment:
>>44267459

“So, uh.” Vyx asks, pointing her pair of wicked handguns back and forth between targets. “Did we decide whether these things are friend or foe?”

“They haven’t attacked us yet, but keep in mind th—“

Ayla is interrupted—crashing, and more screaming. This time, from all directions, as the sound of collapsing shelves and shattering glass plunges you into sudden severity and turmoil. Shadows close in on you at high speed from all directions; someone, or something collides with you from behind, sending you stumbling forward, barely able to keep your balance. You stabilize yourself, managing to avoid bumping into other members of the veritable flood of homunculi that's filled the room, drunkenly wandering about with no direction between them.

Taller than you, you can't quite see past them, only managing to catch occasional glimpses of your party through the flood. Some of them have sharpened body parts—not least for those obsidian spikes serving as legs, which you imagine would crush anyone who fell in short order. You can barely hear over the sounds that fill the room: screaming, metallic grinding, objects shattering.

> Try to push through to another member of the raid.
> Kjorikos can't be far from here. Look for the final room, rounding up anyone you can on the way.
> Time to find out how strong they are. Draw your sword and cut a path to the nearest ally.
> Other.

Your sword won't budge. It gives you the impression that you've struck an object, but your weapon has still somehow become embedded within. Back and forth, then up and down—you first wrest it from her grip, before redoubling your effort, pushing your blade forward and dragging it downward diagonally to finish the cut, barely managing to saw through her body.

Jeweled legs fall to their knees, motionless, as her torso tumbles backwards.

But there's no death message yet. You shudder, as her arms move to catch her fall, before her head hits the Sanctum floor. Two more dolls move in from either side to fill the empty space, reaching out towards you, and listening for the sound of stone grinding on glass over the screaming—now crying—you think there are more approaching from behind.

> Duck low. Slide between the attackers and finish off the wounded one.

44268424.name: Sylvetica
44268424.comment:
>>44268193
> [[ 94 ]]

Engaging in the world of Broken Sky Online feels disturbingly realistic at times, but one of the most jarring differences is that you don't feel quite so anchored to the earth. You're much stronger, and it seems that gravity applies to you differently at times. You've made some pretty daring maneuvers yourself, and you've seen Nel take falls that you're certain would break both of your legs in real life.
 
You make about as powerful a leap as you can, and stop at the height of your jump, with one foot balanced on either of your attackers' heads. A hand swipes upward at your ankle, and you move instinctively, jumping to plant both feet on the forehead of another doll—and again as that one fails to maintain her balance.

You've always hated platforming, but this is working out nicely, all things considered. About ten feet towards the hallway, atop the sea of dolls, you see Tatsumaki, who seems to have adopted the same tactic as you. She's dodging about as efficiently, but her balance is looking a lot better than yours; at the very least, it looks prettier. From here, you can also hear Vyx more clearly, shouting expletives over the crying—you can see where she is in the crowd, as she's firing her guns straight up into the air as quickly as they'll shoot. Eunoia is fluttering around in circles over the mob, whistling happily.

You're not sure where everyone else is. Hopefully, no one's been trampled. Honestly, you're not even sure what to do now. You didn't really think this was going to work at all.

> Write-in.

“Tatsumaki!” As she looks over at you, you point in Vyx's direction, and head that way to meet her—extraction time. You watch Eunoia to keep your bearings, and the two of you cross the unruly platforms in opposite directions to meet in the middle, dropping into a dead space in the crowd where the Gunner waits on the floor, alternating between firing upward and scurrying around on her back.

“Oh, fuck, where did you come from?” Vyx asks. “We are so dead.”

“Crowdsurfing.” You respond. “Can you get up there?”

“Fuck no I can't.” She says. “Are you insane?”

“What? Bullshit you can't. I saw you cartwheeling around shooting two guns a few minutes ago.” You shake your head.

“This is different!” She struggles to her feet, scanning her surroundings for an opening in the crowd. “Can't you see what's happening?”

You sigh.

“Tatsumaki,” You say, motioning her toward Vyx, then making a scooping motion with your arms. “Take her. You're carrying less than I am.”

“You want her to do what?” Vyx asks—then Tatsumaki sweeps her off the ground, bracing her knees and back with one arm each. Before you can afford further instructions, Tatsumaki leaps upward again, carrying Vyx atop the crowd with her.

> Follow Eunoia in search of Aelriss.
> Message someone. (Write-in)
> Head for the hallway.
> Other.

There's a little bit of space in the crowd for you to move through, and you think you see where Eunoia's been fluttering closest to. Staying low to the ground, you maneuver towards it, attempting to minimize contact with the homunculi surrounding you.

In another opening, you can see she's doing a fairly well job of defending herself. Her weapon—a metal rod—has a long reach, and it doesn't necessarily have to be used so lethally as a sword or gun. > [[ 34 ]]

“Ael, let's make time!” You shout. “Take 'em down!”

With a fierce backhand, your follow-up swing is deflected. It grazes, sparking along the creature's stone arm and bouncing wide of her head. Then, the twin homunculi attack, lashing out at your arm. The claws are not sharp, but they rend flesh as they cross it, as if trailing invisible knives an inch behind them.

> [[ HP: 9 / 35 ]]
> [[ Dazed ]]

They run up your chest, and you tilt your head to the side to avoid an even worse fate—but your shoulder is split open, and blood sprays from the wound. It hurts, and you stumble, falling onto your back.

“Ashe!” Aelriss shouts, moving to parry an incoming attack. She deflects a strike headed your way with her staff—but isn't watching behind her, and an obsidian spike pierces her abdomen from behind, visible to you from below as it exits the other side.

She winces, clutching the bloody spike tip at her front, before falling forward and landing face-down next to you, blood mingling on the Sanctum floor.

The scratching of stone on glass draws closer.

> Write-in.

“You alright?” You ask.

“Yeah, barely.” Aelriss responds, as the two of you carefully maneuver throughout the thinning crowd. There's space now, thankfully, and it grows wider as the remainder of the homunculi begin to disappear, stumbling and falling down the stairs or shuffling back into the compartments behind the windows, vanishing into darkness. Vyx and Tatsumaki are visible at the corner far ahead, and you see Nel shuffling out from under a bookcase now that the noise has stopped.

“Thanks for the assist.” You say.

“You too.” She responds. “Nice plan, by the way.”

“I didn't really have a whole lot to go by.” You shrug. “But yeah, I've done better.”

Toward the center of the room, a translucent red dome—apex no more than three or four feet off the ground—shields the other members of the party, and fades quickly once the screaming and crying comes to a stop.

“Oh, wow.” Aelriss nudges you. “That's Kainzo's...?”

“Must be.” Nel says. “I can't imagine he uses it often—probably none of the Guardians break theirs out frequently, on account of drawing attention.”

“As if Liza could resist flying everywhere?” You ask. You wouldn't have a whole lot to go by on that, but almost falling to your death was pretty fun that one time, were it not for the 'death' qualifier.

“Whatever the case, it looks powerful.” Aelriss says. “Kainzo! Was that what I think it was?”

“Walk and talk.” Kainzo responds, the remainder of the group in tow. “There aren't that many places to go in this Sanctum. I've a feeling most of the roads that aren't in the basement lead back here.”

> [[ Continued ]]

“Cat-girl!” Vyx says, still hefted in Tatsumaki's arms, as you and the group begin to pass. You hear Kainzo sigh on your behalf. “You're so strong. I love you now. Take me away!”

Tatsumaki gives her a confused look, before suddenly collapsing, leaving the two of them in a stunned, tangled heap on the floor.

“Huh. Fatigue.” Andor says, glancing them over. “Doing acrobatics like that while carrying so much weight catches up with you. I haven't seen anyone manage it for so long, to be honest.”

“Hey, are you calling me fat?” Vyx's voice is muffled, face pressed against the ground. “Take it back.”

You've been down these hallways before. Glassy walls, with gold-leaf trim. All alike, an immaculate setting that derides your eyes for believing this place is the slightest bit clean. Screaming still echoes in your ears, and blood stains your armor as it once did these floors. Perhaps, you think, the power of Artifice was built upon a foundation of jealousy, bloodshed, and indecency.

Or perhaps all these goddamn roleplayers are getting in your head again. You sigh. Nel's map is accurate—at least, what he was able to make before the dolls blocked him off. Smooth stone doors, set perfectly into the adjacent walls, dot the hallways. Most are sealed, and do not open. Few others might well be worth searching. But what you seek, you see ahead.

> [[ Ancient Cathedral: Sanctum of Kjorikos – The Observatory // PVP Disabled ]]

> [[ Continued ]]

44272512.name: Sylvetica
44272512.comment:
>>44272433

At the back of this landing, a small staircase leads up to a massive, wooden double-door, decorated in iron and gold: the Observatory. The remainder of the room is uneventful, save for one thing: a banquet table—seated for ten, with dishes brimming with exotic-looking fruits and meats. In the center, a number of empty glasses surround a small, ornate bronze fountain, which recycles a pure-looking liquid, wine-red. Adjacent, another bowl stacked high with more fruits of other types, glowing beneath chandelier-light from above.

“Opulent.” Ayla says, an air of sarcasm in her voice. You're rolling over your inventory—the walk has been quiet, rife with tension.

“I'm taking all of this on the way out.” Aelriss says.

“We'll split it down the middle.” Donnel nudges. “Square?”

“Incorrect. The officers' room at the Writ Keepers' hall is in need of new decorations.” Dorian says. “Ayla, I'll secure you the lion's share.”

“Hold on,” You suggest. “It could be a trap.”

“He's right.” Kainzo says, staying the group before they advance. “A deception like that would be practically normal in the lower branches.”

“This doesn't look like it.” Nel moves forward, investigating the table. “At least, not a traditional one, anyway. Might be some kind of a rest area, or just decoration? I'm assuming that's the boss room up ahead.”

“That's what they WANT you to think.” Vyx folds her arms.

“I'm inclined to believe the opposite of whatever she does.” Ayla points at Vyx.

“How about someone jumps in and grabs something, and Eunoia can fix 'em up if it's poisoned?” Donnel says. “I volunteer Dorian.”

“Eunoia's spent for another few minutes.” Aelriss says. “Had a close call back there.”

Tatsumaki gives you an inquisitive look, then shrugs.

> Write-in.

You pop the moonroot herb into your mouth with an awfully loud, unsatisfying crunch. Still next to you, Aelriss winces on your behalf.

> [[ PP: 6 / 6 ]]
> [[ Moonroot Poisoning: Dizzy ]]

“Well, uh.” Evidently done checking the table and chairs for traps, Nel's going over the assortment of foods. “There's like, a ton of moonroot over here.”

In quiet anticipation of things to come, you gulp down a lesser healing potion as well.

> [[ HP: 16 / 35 ]]

The party begins to surround the table, and you look over what Nel's got his eye on.

> Inventory [[ platter ]]
pickled moonroot x8

“Looks legit.” You say, sarcastically. It's a number of small, sealed jars containing a faintly-glowing bluish suspension.

“Maybe it's a purified restorative, like moonroot elixir.” Aelriss says. “Or, maybe it's just been fermenting for so long that it's twice as toxic as the raw herb. That sounds more likely.”

“Hey, look on the bright side.” Vyx says. “Twice the toxicity means twice the potency, y'know.”

“She's got a point.” Donnel shrugs. “Kind of a stupid one, but a point nontheless.”

“Is the implication here that people used to just eat this stuff for fun?” Aelriss asks.

“You probably had to be a little intoxicated to invent the kinds of stuff we've seen in here.” Ayla shrugs. “So, yeah, I guess. Take it if you want it, but don't make it your first resort.”

“What about the fountain?” You ask, dipping your finger tentatively. It doesn't seem to have any effect—when you touch it to your tongue, the effect is instantaneous.

> [[ HP: 31 / 35 ]]
> [[ Moonroot Poisoning: Dizzy ]]
> [[ Stunned ]]
> [[ Paralyzed ]]

A single drop, and the worst of your wounds close in an instant. But your muscles lock up; your skin tightens uncomfortably, and you collapse into a sitting position. You're stunned for another couple of seconds—then, left in a state where you can't do much more than talk and move your arms.

“Ascheritte! Are you alright?” Kainzo asks.

“Fine?” You say, through clenched teeth.

“Vitae.” Nel says, looking over a full glass. “Looks like it's a powerful restorative.”

> [[ Continued ]]

“Think we can throw this stuff at the boss?” You ask. “We could open with a stun.”

“Doubt it.” Nel says. “If it worked on contact, you'd have been knocked out when you touched it. We should just use it to heal in shifts to save supplies.”

Time passes as the members of the raid imbibe the scarlet liquid, one or two at a time, wounds closing.

“Everyone's alright, I surmise?” Kainzo asks.

“Nel, you're doing good?” You ask.

“Hangin' in there.” He replies, taking a deep breath. “Maybe I'm a little nervous.”

“Well, don't worry. Kjorikos might be a little cross at me specifically. Might have stepped on his toes a little bit, with the tomb ransacking and homunculus-smashing.” You reply, then shrug. “So, no one go do anything crazy trying to save me, if things get bad.”

“I wasn't planning on it.” Dorian rolls his eyes.

“Aelriss, you're fine?” You turn to look at her. “I saw you killed one of the dolls, so...”

“As I've ever been, Ashe.” She responds. “And I know. I'll be on my toes. If anything, I'll stick with you.”

“Donnel, you said you were low on recovery items?” Kainzo asks. “How is everyone doing down that avenue?”

“I've got enough for the fight.” Donnel says. “I was just concerned about having to use them to prepare for the fight, instead.”

“Same,” Ayla replies. “I've got a bomb left, too, and I know exactly where I'm putting it.”

Tatsumaki gives a thumbs-up.

“I think we're ready, then.” Kainzo says. “We know our formation...”

“And we've proven already that we operate on the outer fringe of strategy.” Andor adds.

“Nothing's left, then?” Aelriss asks.

44274777.name: Sylvetica
44274777.comment:
>>44274019
> [[ Ancient Cathedral: Sanctum of Kjorikos – The Observatory // PVP Disabled ]]

Through the enormous doors, an even more jarring disconnect awaits, as the raid crosses the threshold into what seems like another world altogether.

> [[ Sylvetica // PVP Disabled ]]

At your back, the whole of the temple—or the portion you can see from here, embedded in the rock face that extends upward to melt into the sky, and reaches the horizon to your left and right both—waits, looking rustic and decrepit in its exterior.

You stand in a meadow, geographically not unlike the first place you experienced upon beginning the game. You're on the edge of a lush forest. There are mountains visible in the distance, and you can hear birds chirping overhead. You're warmed by an illusory sun, high in the sky.

“Oh, damn.” Ayla says. “Don't show me a place like this if you're not going to give me time to explore it...”

“On your guard, Ayla.” Kainzo nods, weapon ready. “Remember. There's an Aetheric Resonator downstairs with your name on it.”

“It's got all of our names on it, Kainzo.” Aelriss grumbles, as the raid spreads out in the meadow. “What do you suppose this place is, anyway?”

“A recreation.” Dorian says. “Is it not obvious? Whatever happened to old Sylvetica—Kjorikos wanted to get it back. The same goes for Velika. He was merely stuck in the past. Someone who must have been so powerful couldn't even move forward where it counted.”

“Indeed.” An unknown man's voice sounds, echoic. Behind, you hear a door slamming—typical. It continues. “There are none so strong as to leave this past behind.”

The sky begins to darken, and you feel energy welling up around you. The members of the party assume fighting stances, looking each other over briefly.

“Move!” You shout. “Now!”

At your back, the whole of the temple—or the portion you can see from here, embedded in the rock face that extends upward to melt into the sky, and reaches the horizon to your left and right both—waits, looking rustic and decrepit in its exterior.

You stand in a meadow, geographically not unlike the first place you experienced upon beginning the game. You're on the edge of a lush forest. There are mountains visible in the distance, and you can hear birds chirping overhead. You're warmed by an illusory sun, high in the sky.

“Oh, damn.” Ayla says. “Don't show me a place like this if you're not going to give me time to explore it...”

“On your guard, Ayla.” Kainzo nods, weapon ready. “Remember. There's an Aetheric Resonator downstairs with your name on it.”

“It's got all of our names on it, Kainzo.” Aelriss grumbles, as the raid spreads out in the meadow. “What do you suppose this place is, anyway?”

“A recreation.” Dorian says. “Is it not obvious? Whatever happened to old Sylvetica—Kjorikos wanted to get it back. The same goes for Velika. He was merely stuck in the past. Someone who must have been so powerful couldn't even move forward where it counted.”

“Indeed.” An unknown man's voice sounds, echoic. Behind, you hear a door slamming—typical. It continues. “There are none so strong as to leave this past behind.”

The sky begins to darken, and you feel energy welling up around you. The members of the party assume fighting stances, looking each other over briefly.

“Move!” You shout. “Now!”

44274824.name: Sylvetica
44274824.comment:
>>44274777

“Had you only known the world that was.” A lance of purple lightning utterly annihilates what was the center of your group a moment ago, as you dive and dart in all directions, turning to search for the source of the attack and organize some sort of fighting formation. You smell ozone; divots of broken earth rain down, and a cloud of smoke and dust drifts downwind. “Had you only known the one I loved. You too would find it beautiful. You too would feel weak.”

“Yet now, you are borne upwards, toward the sky. To partake of our past? You will find nothing awaiting you there.” Then, the ground trembles—for only a moment, before pillars and barricades of earth and stone erupt from underground, splitting trees and destroying rocks. You lose sight of the others as you move to avoid the attacks from below; Tatsumaki dodges past you, into the forest, and you hear the sound of handcasters firing, likely Ayla or Vyx. “We share the same fate. You will be corrupted by memory.”

The earth at your feet breaks, and you tumble further through the trees, bracing yourself against a newly formed stone wall as you come to a stop on your feet. He lands mere feet away from you in a wreath of violet fire that scorches the meadow grass. He is bigger than you, armored and cloaked, with a hood pulled over his head and a metal mask disguising his face. He appears ancient, as if imprisoned in a man-shaped shell of rust.

But he is a man—humanoid, at least—and speaks with an unusual awareness of context. You thought only players were human. You scan him up and down for a Unique Identifier to make sure. Nothing.

“Ascheritte.” He speaks in a grim tone, and your blood runs cold.

You've never fought a spellcaster before, but you swear someone told you once they were pretty dangerous. You don't see the others.

> Write-in.

>>44275029

“I'm guessing you're expecting an apology?” Mostly, you're wondering what he is. How smart is he, and what is he capable of? You make sure to speak loudly.

“I wanted to see what you would do.” He pauses, motionless, deliberating. “You and I have something in common. I am haunted. Now, you are also.”

“Yeah. I've disrespected Velika's memory, if that's what you mean. But haven't you done the same thing?” You ask. “You made a bunch of dolls—imitations. How's that for honoring the past?”

“Could you, in good faith, believe a world so idyllic was ever meant to change? Is it reasonable, for all we care about to be taken from us in a moment?” A mound pushes out of the surface of the hardened clay wall nearby, and you shy away from it as it slowly takes the shape and color of a man—before melting into the earth below. “I believed artifice could create anything. But too late, I realized that even with the higher elements at my disposal, it could create only in imitation. Even with the essence of Life between my fingertips, I could not give this world life again. You and I are condemned. My curse is now yours, and you will never be free.”

“I'm not so sure.”

“You want to revive your dead, do you not? There is a boy among you who believes there is no greater purpose.” Kjorikos begins to draw a circle of flames in the air, and you stand ready to move. “You will come to see that loss is reality, no matter what strength you possess.”

> [[ Continued ]]

44275574.name: Sylvetica
44275574.comment:
>>44275044

> [[ 43 ]]

The violet fire marches towards you slowly, and you dive to one side, circling around him. You have to keep moving—the projectile is chasing you, as Kjorikos turns and watches. Too late, you see why; a hand from beneath the earth catches your ankle, and you're suddenly bathed in fire.

> [[ HP: 21 / 35 ]]

Like the Obsidian Pegasus's attack, it feels cold. You're surrounded by white light, and tendrils of ice creep across the inside of your skull. Bastard sword in hand, you swing downward to cut yourself free from the appendage, and continue your stride, minimizing contact with the earth.

His movements are minimal. No opportunity looks superior to another, and you move inside, taking a swing. He lowers himself a bit, deflecting your blade with the back of his armored gauntlet, then levitates a few feet backwards, the clay wall behind him sinking back into the earth. No damage, it seems—but it's all you needed, as red rings encircle your body. Haste.

“Ascheritte!” You hear movement in the woods behind you. The party's coming to join. Time slows, or your reflexes speed up, and you brandish your weapon, which leaves afterimages in the air.

> Move back to meet the party.
> All-out attack. Lead the charge against the Artificer.
> Write-in.

He's buffeted with caster fire from somewhere in the woods, and raises his arms to shield himself, preparing another attack. That must be the opening. You charge forward, still adhering to the strategy of avoiding contact with the earth where possible. Where a pillar emerged previously, a tree is tilted at an angle between the two of you, and you springboard off of it as you close the distance at incredible speed; not even a levitating target is safe from you.

Your first strike is from overhead, with two hands, and he blocks it with his own armored palms. You remember—this is the mistake you made when you faced off with Anaximander. But you were slower then. You pull away, the tip of your blade leaving a crescent of flames in the air as you circle back for an upward strike.

It hits, solid but shallow; you see flecks of rust loosed from the impact site as he increases his own speed, coming to a landing a few feet away from you. 

“Stay off the ground whenever you can!” You shout. Kainzo and Tatsumaki are catching up, in time for the Artificer's next flurry. Violet orbs flicker into existence in an arc over his head, twisting for a moment before unleashing a flurry of lightning bolts at you and the group further behind. You hear a shout from somewhere over your shoulder, but can't give up an inch.

“Ashe, go straight ahead!” Kainzo lands at your side, having caught up from behind. You heed the command, and he extends his free hand as he lands, casting an enormous, translucent scarlet barrier between you and the Artificer. The next salvo of bolts is deflected off, leaving spiderweb cracks in the barrier like glass.

From overhead, Eunoia lands on your shoulder, whistling gravely.

> [[ HP: 22 / 35 ]]

How far does this place go? You're running out of time with Haste.

44276409.name: Sylvetica
44276409.comment:
>>44275913
> [[ 68 ]]

“Tatsumaki! Ascheritte! Get ready!” Kainzo shouts. “Barrier's going down in three, two...!”

Kjorikos lands—with incredible force that belies his lightweight appearance—and prepares to stand his ground. That's fine. You wanted more time to attack anyway.

Tatsumaki speeds up, reaching him first. She rises up from his side, throwing a number of lightning-quick jabs. Light punches hit home, striking the side of his chest, and she reels back for a haymaker; the Artificer displays a surprising martial prowess, or at least overwhelming strength, as he catches her by the wrist and guides her into a take-down that sends her rag-doll bouncing at least ten feet through the knee-high grass. He chases the technique with a bolt of lightning; you don't see if it hits, but merely hope it didn't.

You and Kainzo arrive simultaneously. His swing speed is noticeably slower than yours, and you time your strikes with his to minimize the Artificer's ability to dodge. A horizontal swing from the Crimson Guardian; the Artificer ducks low, falling to one knee to avoid it, but doesn't have enough time to counterattack him before you go for a combination. Your blade looses more rust from his armor, then, leaves a deep gash across his mask, sparking as it does. But pulling a hand through empty air, Kjorikos draws an enormous sword—a withering, sparking lance of violet energy—and swings it in a wide horizontal arc, forcing you and Kainzo to the ground as every tree surrounding you is cut down, beginning to slowly fall inward.

“Out with you.” A cloud begins to collect over the clearing, lightning crackling within. “Perhaps you'll thank me for this, Ascheritte."

44276436.name: Sylvetica
44276436.comment:
>>44276409

“Kainzo! Barrier back up, now!” You hear Nel shout, and see his form silhouetted in the purple light overhead as he leaps toward Kjorikos from behind. The Artificer turns, appearing briefly nonplussed, as Nel lands feet first on his chest, grabbing him by the head. There's a distinct pause before Kjorikos grabs him, throwing him aside in a dusting of indigo flames with a single gauntleted hand.

Kainzo raises his barrier, shielding the two of you in time for an enormous explosion of force and wild, coiling energy to erupt from the Artificer's direction—you hear Kjorikos grunt, in what sounds like pain, and see his silhouette levitate deeper into the woods, chased away by more caster fire from outside the clearing.

“Huh.” Kainzo says, dusting himself off as the barrier dissipates. “Kid planted one of Ayla's bombs.”

> [[ HP: 23 / 35 ]]

Nel and Tatsumaki join you, looking pretty badly beaten up already. You see the others pulling themselves over the downed trees to meet up with you in the clearing. Eunoia leaves your shoulder to reunite with Aelriss.

“Damnit, he's too quick.” Donnel pants.

“We've got to go after him.” Andor replies.

“No deal. I was ahead of you guys for a while.” Nel says. “He's leading us toward a cliff. This place empties into a proper abyss.”

“So, what do we do?” Aelriss says. “I mean, if we corner him, we'll actually be able to attack him all at once.”

“But he's got no problem attacking all of us at once.” Kainzo says, then examines a faintly-glowing bracer around his left wrist. “Bastion is down for five minutes this time. I think we're gonna have to find a way to lure him into another clearing. Somewhere we've got cover.”

“Uh huh.” Vyx says. “You have any ideas as to how we're going to lure him out? He practically controls the weather in here.”

> Suggest engaging him against the cliff.
> Suggest an alternate course of action. (Write-in.)
> Other.
